channel.title: NYT > Obituaries
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: John Shirreffs, 80, Dies; Trainer of a Nearly Perfect Horse
item.description: He guided Zenyatta, a spectacular mare, to 19 consecutive wins and won the Kentucky Derby in 2005 with Giacomo, a 50-1 long shot.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Howard Lipin/San Diego Union-Tribune, via ZUMA Press
item.media:description: The horse trainer John Shirreffs walks Zenyatta, his star mare, after her morning workout in Del Mar, Calif., in 2010.

item.title: Michael Silverblatt, NPR’s ‘Bookworm’ Who Interviewed Authors, Dies at 73
item.description: His public radio show, “Bookworm,” was a literary salon of the air for 33 years, drawing guests like Joan Didion, Susan Sontag and David Foster Wallace.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Michael Silverblatt in 1999 while hosting “Bookworm” on KCRW, a public radio station on the campus of Santa Monica College. “The purpose of the show is to help my listeners look through writers’ eyes,” he said.

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.description: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Mr. Wren in an undated photo. Explaining why he went into journalism, he said, “I wanted to find a job where I could go out and satisfy my curiosity and have somebody pay for it.”

item.title: Eric Dane, McSteamy on ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ Dies at 53 After Battling ALS
item.description: His breakout role came in 2006 as the handsome Dr. Mark Sloan, nicknamed McSteamy, the head of plastic surgery at a Seattle hospital. He died 10 months after announcing his A.L.S. diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Eric Dane revealed in April 2025 that he had A.L.S.

item.title: Doug Moe, 87, N.B.A. Coach as Freewheeling as His Style of Play, Dies
item.description: A former college All-American touched by scandal, he was irreverent and unpredictable as he piloted his fast-paced Nuggets and Spurs.
item.dc:creator: Harvey Araton
item.media:description: Doug Moe coaching the Denver Nuggets in 1985. A sports journalist’s dream, he was once fined by the N.B.A. front office for throwing water on a referee.

item.title: José van Dam, Suave and Riveting Opera Star, Dies at 85
item.description: One of the most esteemed singers of his era, he had a wide repertoire that included Mozart, Wagner and the title role in Messiaen’s epic “St. François d’Assise.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: José van Dam in 1987 as the title character in Wagner’s “The Flying Dutchman” at the San Francisco Opera.

item.title: Billy Steinberg, Hitmaking Lyricist of Madonna’s ‘Like a Virgin,’ Dies at 75
item.description: He co-wrote five pop-rock songs that soared to No. 1 in the 1980s and shared in a Grammy for producing Celine Dion’s 1996 album “Falling Into You.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Larry Busacca/Getty Images for Songwriters Hall of Fame
item.media:description: Billy Steinberg performing at the Songwriters Hall of Fame ceremony in 2011. With fellow inductee Tom Kelly, Mr. Steinberg wrote hundreds of songs, including “True Colors,” a hit for Cyndi Lauper.

item.title: Cees Nooteboom, Voyaging Author of Enigmatic Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific Dutch writer of fiction, poetry and travel books, he was often mentioned as a potential recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Cees Nooteboom in 2015. The author of dozens of works of fiction, poetry, journalism and travel writing, he was perennially mentioned as a possible recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.

item.title: David Hays, 95, Dies; Top Broadway Designer and Theater of Deaf Founder
item.description: He created sets and lighting for dozens of productions, including “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” and established a new art form with his theater of the deaf, combining sign and spoken language.
item.dc:creator: Howard Fishman

item.title: Writing an Ancient Egyptian Afterlife, in 21 Feet of Scroll
item.description: How would a New York Times obituary writer measure up to the scribes of the Book of the Dead? He found out at the Brooklyn Museum.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Jo Ann Bass, Matriarch of Joe’s Stone Crab in Miami Beach, Dies at 94
item.description: For decades, she oversaw a money-gushing South Florida restaurant that has drawn celebrities like Frank Sinatra, Muhammad Ali and Madonna.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: From 1983: Fania Fénelon, 74; Memoirs Described Auschwitz Singing
item.description: In “Playing for Time,” she recounted how singing in an all-female orchestra while in a concentration camp saved her from death.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: From 2001: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.description: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Martin

item.title: From 1966: Anna Akhmatova, Leading Soviet Poet, Is Dead
item.description: She was a towering figure in Soviet literature who was once silenced in a Stalinist literary purge.
item.dc:creator: Special to The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Akhmatova in the late 1920s.

item.title: From 2009: Millvina Dean, Titanic’s Last Survivor, Dies at 97
item.description: She was just 9 weeks old when she was lowered to safety in a mail sack, surviving the worst maritime disaster in history.
item.dc:creator: John F. Burns
item.media:description: Millvina Dean in 1994 peering through a porthole that was part of an exhibit called “The Wreck of the Titanic” at the National Maritime Museum.

item.title: Frederick Vreeland, Diplomat and Spy Who Served With Style, Dies at 98
item.description: A son of the influential fashion editor Diana Vreeland, he had an upbringing well suited to his overt and covert duties during the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Jesse Jackson: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The civil rights leader was one of the country’s most influential Black figures.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: Jesse Jackson, Charismatic Champion of Civil Rights, Dies at 84
item.description: An impassioned orator, he was a moral and political force, forming a “rainbow coalition” of poor and working-class people and seeking the presidency. His mission, he said, was “to transform the mind of America.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Applebome
item.media:credit: Keith C. Meyers/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson acknowledged the applause of delegates at the 2000 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.

item.title: Frederick Wiseman, 96, Penetrating Documentarian of Institutions, Dies
item.description: He exposed abuses in films like “Titicut Follies,” a once-banned portrait of a mental hospital, but ranged widely in subject matter, from a Queens neighborhood to a French restaurant.
item.dc:creator: John Anderson
item.media:description: Mr. Wiseman in an undated photo. “I don’t know if I can offer a general definition of what I’m doing,” he said in 2011, “except to say I’m trying to create dramatic structures out of ordinary experience.”

item.title: Robert Duvall, ‘Godfather’ and ‘Apocalypse Now’ Actor, Dies at 95
item.description: An Oscar winner, he was known for disappearing into wide-ranging roles in movies like “Apocalypse Now” and “The Godfather” and in the television series “Lonesome Dove.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:description: In a long and varied career, Robert Duvall was nominated for seven Academy Awards for acting, and won once.

item.title: Richard Ottinger, 97, Dies; Fought for the Environment in Congress
item.description: A New York Democrat, he spent 16 years in the House over two stretches, beginning in 1965, championing the health of the Hudson River and opposing the Vietnam War.
item.dc:creator: Joseph P. Fried and Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Richard Ottinger in 1970. He served six years in the House of Representatives beginning in 1965 and another 10 years starting in 1975.

item.title: Henrike Naumann, Artist Set to Represent Germany at Venice Biennale, Dies at 41
item.description: Her death from cancer was the second sudden loss for this year’s edition. Naumann’s exhibition will still go ahead in May, according to a statement.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Henrike Naumann, who was born in East Germany, became known for installations featuring household items that reflect historical and political events.

item.title: Dana Eden, Co-Creator of ‘Tehran,’ Dies During Filming of Fourth Season
item.description: Ms. Eden, 52, who was also an executive producer of the Emmy-winning show, was found in a hotel room in Athens. Greek police said they did not suspect foul play.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Dana Eden at the premier of Season 2 of “Tehran” in New York in 2022.

item.title: Jerry Kennedy, Who Helped Define Music in Nashville, Dies at 85
item.description: A guitarist and record producer, he played a role in creating hits by popular singers like Roger Miller, Roy Orbison, Tom T. Hall and Tammy Wynette.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:description: Jerry Kennedy in the 1970s posing at the Mercury Records studio control board in Nashville. “Jerry is truly one of the lead architects in the creation of the Nashville sound,” said Marty Stuart, a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.

item.title: How The Times Remembered 15 Winter Olympics Greats
item.description: Obituaries have memorialized the lives of a figure-skating trailblazer, a “Miracle on Ice” hockey player, a bobsledder who overcame blindness, and more.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe and Amisha Padnani
item.media:description: Rosi Mittermaier of Germany competing in 1969. She went on win two women’s Alpine skiing events in the 1976 Olympics and narrowly missed winning a third.

item.title: Alfred Blumstein, Who Transformed the Study of Crime, Dies at 95
item.description: An engineer by training, he used systems theory and quantitative analysis to examine criminal behavior, revealing the systemic patterns of crime.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: King Leatherbury, Trainer and Trader of Horses, Dies at 92
item.description: He trained mostly lesser-known, cheaper thoroughbreds in Maryland and was the fifth-winningest trainer in North American history.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: King Leatherbury at Laurel Park racetrack in Maryland in 2003. He was inducted into the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in 2015.

item.title: ElRoy Face, Ace Forkballer and Effective Closer for Pirates, Dies at 97
item.description: Face was one of the first major-league hurlers to make the closer job a specialty. Not an overpowering pitcher, he finagled outs with a tricky forkball.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:description: ElRoy Face followed through after serving up a pitch against the Yankees at Yankee Stadium in the fifth game of the 1960 World Series. Face helped take the Pirates to a stunning defeat of the Yankees that year.

item.title: Roy Medvedev, Soviet Era Historian and Dissident, Is Dead at 100
item.description: His score of books and hundreds of essays documented Stalinist executions, Communist repressions and censorship, and the transition to post-Soviet Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Roy Medvedev in Moscow in 1990. In the West, he was known as the most independent historian of the Soviet era.

item.title: David J. Farber, ‘Grandfather of the Internet,’ Dies at 91
item.description: A researcher, professor and federal policy adviser, he guided students who went on to do groundbreaking work in connecting the world online.
item.dc:creator: Peter Wayner
